posts.post:
Anyone else feel like everyone is excluding you/hates you?
I'm in a training group at work and can't even make eye contact with people because I feel like I'm being judged so hard.  I rarely talk to my co-workers because I'm afraid of saying something cringey or embarrassing myself (which usually happens when I talk), but my supervisors made a point of me not talking and that I need to talk/participate more.   So today I tried to talk and have some humor but I found myself being ignored, or when I talked, someone else would talk over me.   We all met at the same time, and yet I'm already seeing my coworkers walk with eachother during lunch hour and no one ever invites me.   I just wish I could feel natural around people, and be a likeable person. Any time I talk to someone, I feel the need to micro-manage my facial expressions. I hate smiling because I smile so awkwardly. I hate people making eye contact with me. I can never think of things to talk about.   I haven't had any friends for 11 years and I'm just sick of social interaction feeling like work... I just want to be a normal person. But I'm not. It just feels like everyone in the world is in this special social club and I'm not allowed in.
posts.Post Summary:
The main self state in this post is maladaptive and is centered around the expectation that the writer's relatedness needs will not be met, as she expects her social status to stay the same - alone. she feels lonely because as she is living her expectation of life, and views others as if they are ignoring him/her. the writers behaves in ways that distance him/herself from others, and because he/she views themselves in a critical way as awkward, they behave in ways that might be counterintuitive and self-sabotaging, such as micro-managing his/her's facial expressions and not smiling. 
The other self state in the post is centered around the desire to be liked, and feel connected to others. the writer behaves in ways that help this desire come to be, as they tried to talk to others. They also view others as somewhat caring for their needs.

B-O.highlighted_evidence: today I tried to talk and have some humor

C-O.Category: (1) Perception of the other as related
C-O.highlighted_evidence: my supervisors made a point of me not talking and that I need to talk/participate more

D.Category: (1) Relatedness

posts.post:
Almost went out with coworkers... but I didn't... it's really irritating.
Started my first adult job a little while ago.  Coworkers invited me out to a pub to play pool and drink. Which I've wanted to do for years. I've always wanted to have someone or people to have fun with. Especially in a pub cause drinking helps me not be completely antisocial.   Anyway I said that I can't cause I'm getting picked up.  Turns out my ride had to drive into town later on anyway so I could have gone... potentially made friends with my coworkers.... I'm so disappointed.
posts.Post Summary:
The main self state in this post is adaptive. it's centered around the writer's desire to relate and have friends. this desire is finally almost becoming a reality, as the writer view's others as reciprocating her relatedness needs and being related to her. she is feeling depressed because this reality did not come to be in the end.
The maladaptive self state is comprised of the writer's cognition of herself in a critical way, as antisocial and someone who needs to drink in order to be social.

C-O.Category: (1) Perception of the other as related
C-O.highlighted_evidence: Coworkers invited me out to a pub to play pool and drink. Which I've wanted to do for years.

posts.post:
Is work supposed to suck...?
Been wanting an office job for ages after working lots of min wage jobs and I finally got one paying a livable wage (just barely) and absolutely HATE IT.   Idk where to go from here. I think about trucking but I hear that's a rough life and you work 70+ hours a week.   Everything feels like it either pays minimum wage, you work crazy long hours, or the job drives you insane.
posts.Post Summary: The main self state in the post is maladaptive and centers around the writer's feeling despair, as if they are stuck. There's an expectation that things will not get better, because all the available options/alternatives seem bad to the writer. The other self state is adaptive, an is comprised of the desire to succeed in finding a well paying job. The writer behaves in ways that help achieve this wish, like actively searching for one and thinking about possible solutions to the problems they go through with this search.

B-S.highlighted_evidence: I think about trucking

posts.post:
Anyone else feel like they are nothing....? Not sure how to explain it
I don't consider myself someone that matters if that makes sense. Not in a self pity way, but like. I have barely any life experience, no friends. I haven't traveled, I'm chubby and unfit. I drink tons of alcohol to get rid of my loneliness/depression for a bit.   I feel like I don't even exist. Or it doesn't matter if I do or don't exist. I try to go through life just being blank, and imagining myself as an NPC in a videogame, but I hate it so much...   I hate saying that i don't matter because it sounds so cliche..
posts.Post Summary: The self state in this post is very maladaptive and is centered around the writer's view of themselves as worthless, being very critical of themselves. This cognition is followed by suffering feelings of depression, and to behave in maladaptive ways by drinking alcohol in order to feel less depressed instead of dealing with those feelings in a more adaptive manner. The writer has a very hopeless view of themselves, expressing the expectation that competence needs will not be met.

A.highlighted_evidence: Anyone else feel like they are nothing

B-S.highlighted_evidence: I drink tons of alcohol to get rid of my loneliness/depression for a bit.

C-S.highlighted_evidence: I don't consider myself someone that matters

D.Category: (6) Expectation that competence needs will not be met
D.highlighted_evidence: it doesn't matter if I do or don't exist.

posts.post:
No no no no no... night if drinking with coworkers. First time I've ever done it. It went so bad.. idk where to post this
Idk where to post this but this is my go-to sub...   I'm so mad at myself. This was the first time I've ever gone out for drinks with coworkers . I got SOOOO drunk. So did my coworkers.   I ended up taking a taxi, but I somehow left my glasses in the taxi, I also somehow ended up at a different bar. I only remember cause the guy refused to serve me.   Me, being piss drunk and having no glasses, ended up walking into a TOTAL STRANGERS HOUSE. They were yelling at me and stuff. Ended up being escorted home by police...   I just... need encouraging words not to fucking kill myself at this point. I am such a piece of shit. My family was so worried. Fuck me...
posts.Post Summary: The main self state is maladaptive, centers around the writer's feeling shame. The great shame they feel follows a series of maladaptive behaviors toward the self (drinking heavily) and acting out of control toward others entering a strangers house leading them to be escorted out by the police. The shame is so powerful it leads them to view themselves as worthless. the other self state is adaptive, she is wishing for encouragement from others and soothing words, views her family as relating and worried while behaving in a relating way towards others by asking for this help.

posts.post:
I can't do this anymore. Cops been to the house a couple times because of drinking. About to be kicked out... I need help
Last night I went out with coworkers for drinks. We ended up drinking a lot and I was on an empty stomach. I don't remember much of the night but I do tend to get alcohol-induced psychosis when I get super drunk..   Someone called me a cab. Idk who did it. If it was the bar security or if it was a stranger on the street. I somehow told the cab driver to go to a different pub and I was talking nonsense to the waitress and bartender there. Like literally things that make no sense at all.   So then I left, and was feeling SO lost. I couldnt operate my phone, so i tried walking home. I ended up walking into someone else's house a few blocks down because I thought I lived there. The dude was swearing at me and the cops were called. I tried explaining what was happening but couldnt because of the psychosis. I was just so lost and couldn't get home.   So i ended up being escorted home by police... they talked to my aunt who I'm living with. I'm at the last straw... if anything like this happens again, I'm out..     I just got a betterhelp counselor and we are working on getting me to quit. I can't drink just a few. I'll drink until something bad happens..  Can't get over the shame... I feel so horrible.  I also left my belongings at the strangers house which the police gave to me today.      TLDR: went out for drinks with coworkers, got so drunk that I was having psychosis, managed to walk into a strangers house because I was lost and thought I lived there, and ended up being escorted home by police. Gonna be kicked out if it happens again... I can't get over the shame and guilt..
posts.Post Summary: The main self state in this post is maladaptive, and is centered around the writer's feeling shame. it follows an expectation that when the writer behaves in ways that block they're potential to get better by drinking alcohol they will act out of control, and drink until badly intoxicated (psychosis), not able to self regulate. Under this psychosis, the writer is out of control, behaving in ways that endanger others. The writer also talks very critically towards themselves, in a negative manner. The other self state is adaptive, an centers around the writer's desire to get better, showcasing behavioral signs of self care by going to counceling, and seeking help from others.

B-S.highlighted_evidence: I just got a betterhelp counselor and we are working on getting me to quit

D.Category: (5) Competence, self esteem, self-care
D.highlighted_evidence: I can't do this anymore

A.highlighted_evidence: Can't get over the shame... I feel so horrible.

B-S.highlighted_evidence: We ended up drinking a lot and I was on an empty stomach

B-O.highlighted_evidence: I ended up walking into someone else's house a few blocks down because I thought I lived there.

C-S.highlighted_evidence: I'm at the last straw... if anything like this happens again, I'm out.

posts.post:
How do you deal with the shame..?
I've done so many embarrassing and cringey and bad things when I'm drunk. (99% of the time I'm a harm to myself but family gets very worried)  I just want to hide. Lock myself in my bedroom forever. But I can't.. I gotta work and eat and stuff.   I can't deal with this shame. I'm trying to quit but every failure just ends up with more shame. Being escorted home by police because I walked into a strangers house because I got lost and was blackout drunk, I don't remember what I do half the time when drunk but I'm sure it's cringey and embarrassing.   It's difficult to not go and buy more alcohol right now to deal with the shame.

posts.post:
Can I be sued for trespassing or anything...?
I got super drunk on the weekend. To the point where I had psychosis and couldn't understand basic language. Someone would ask me a question and I'd answer with something totally unrelated.   I took a cab to a different bar and became lost. I ended up walking into someone else's house because I was so confused. I couldn't explain why I was there or what was happening because of the psychosis. They were swearing at me and everything and the cops were called. I did eventually tell them how sorry I was and that I drank too much and I'm lost. Kinda cringey drunk apologizing.  The police took me home and I apologized to them as well.    There was no  harm done. I'm finished drinking. Going to attend AA meetings as well. I'm scared I can be sued for trespassing though. I don't even know what they looked like or where they live...
posts.Post Summary: The main self state in the post is a maladaptive one. The writer feels anxious about the possibility of being sued for trespassing, after drinking so much she entered a psychotic state, and then proceeded to behave in an out of control way and entered a stranger's house. The other self state is an adaptive one. It's composed of the writers with to be be better, resulting in her behaving towards herself in a self care manner by committing to not drinking anymore, and by showing regret and saying sorry to the ones she hurt.

B-S.highlighted_evidence: I'm finished drinking. Going to attend AA meetings as well

B-O.highlighted_evidence: I did eventually tell them how sorry I was

posts.post:
Went to my first AA meeting and I sort of feel bad that I'm not as bad off as everyone else.
I've had cringey moments, I've almost been arrested a few times, I'll drink till I black out every weekend, but man... some of those people have been to jail, spent years HEAVY drinking every single day... I was half of most of their ages though.   I just feel bad because I drink to deal with my emotions and that I'm truly lonely. No friends or anything. Some of those guys had drinking buddies or biker buddies they'd drink with and man that seems so cool. (Not the drinking but just experiencing that). I feel like such a baby
posts.Post Summary: The main self state in this post is an adaptive one. The writer is behaving in a very self caring way by going to AA meetings. The meetings with the other alcoholics makes her view herself in a somewhat positive light, showing self acceptance. It seems she desires connection and relatedness, viewing the other's ability to make friends as cool. the other self state in the post is a maladaptive one, fueled by her affect of loneliness.  She views the alcoholics with her in the meets as damaged, worse than her, but when as part of the comparison with them she calls herself a baby showcasing self criticism.

posts.post:
Just had a dream that reminded me about life 10 years ago
Not sure if this really belongs on the sub, but as soon as I woke up, I was completely blasted with how different I was 10 years ago, and how different my family was.   I miss how things used to be.   Also technology. It's insane what we have now even compared to only 10 years ago. If I were to show my past self my phone, Nintendo switch, or my laptop 2 in 1, he would faint with excitement.   What happened to my will to live? I used to want to do things in life and I had dreams and a lot of excitement for life. Yet now, I barely care at all if I die. I never feel like I matter. I developed an alcohol problem and have almost died multiple times because of it. Man... it's just so bizarre how things change so quickly. 10 years feels like a lifetime ago
posts.Post Summary: The main self state is a maladaptive one, acknowledging how he expects things to not get better. this hopelessness makes him feel depressed, and explains the harmful way he feels about himself, as he views himself as worthless. the alcoholism as a self harm behavior also contributes to his cognition of himself. the adaptive voice is present when the exhibits a slight excitement, joy when speaking about the current age of technology.

A.highlighted_evidence: It's insane what we have now even compared to only 10 years ago
I miss how things used to be.

B-S.highlighted_evidence: I developed an alcohol problem and have almost died multiple times because of it

C-S.highlighted_evidence: . I never feel like I matter

D.Category: (6) Expectation that competence needs will not be met
D.highlighted_evidence: I used to want to do things in life and I had dreams and a lot of excitement for life. Yet now, I barely care at all if I die

posts.post:
Depression is a horrible mental illness. It changes your perception of the world.
I smoked some weed last night, and had the best high I've ever had.   I actually felt... normal. Like... clear. No depression or anxiety. I think I had a sample of what it's like to not have mental illness. I haven't felt that way since I was a child.   I've been on antidepressants and it's not the same. Antidepressants may block the sadness/anxiety. But it's not the same as not having the mental illness.   After experiencing that, I've really realized how my perception of reality has been so incredibly warped from these mental illnesses. I'm so envious of those who don't have it. I feel like it literally causes you to see the world differently.
posts.Post Summary: the main self state is maladaptive. it centers the writer's experience of smoking weed, showcasing self harm behavior, leading him to feel as if he has a distorted, defective perception and feeling desperate. He is envious of others for being non defective, and expects things to stay the same for him. the other self state is adaptive, through his envy for others without depression the writer shows a wish to get better, and felt happy when smoking weed, stating he felt as if he got a glimpse of being normal.

A.highlighted_evidence: I actually felt... normal. Like... clear.

D.Category: (5) Competence, self esteem, self-care
D.highlighted_evidence: I'm so envious of those who don't have it.

A.highlighted_evidence: No depression or anxiety. I think I had a sample of what it's like to not have mental illness. I haven't felt that way since I was a child.

B-S.highlighted_evidence: I smoked some weed last night, and had the best high I've ever had.   I actually felt... normal. Like... clear

C-S.highlighted_evidence: It changes your perception of the world.

C-O.Category: (2) Perception of the other as detached or over attached
C-O.highlighted_evidence: I'm so envious of those who don't have it.

D.Category: (6) Expectation that competence needs will not be met
D.highlighted_evidence: After experiencing that, I've really realized how my perception of reality has been so incredibly warped from these mental illnesses. I'm so envious of those who don't have it. I feel like it literally causes you to see the world differently.

posts.post:
I was feeling amazing this weekend after not drinking. I think I'm starting to not enjoy alcohol.
I had smoked some weed on Friday and felt amazing during that. And I continued to feel amazing during the weekend. I felt GOOD for once. It was so bizarre. No embarassing moments or hangovers.   I actually kinda forgot what it was like to drink. I then, just today, went out and bought a 6 pack of beer because.. I don't know why. Drank 4 of them and felt like garbage. I poured the last 2 cans into the sink. Why do I like that stuff? Or "did" like it. It tastes like crap, and being drunk makes me feel like crap.   I wasn't even drunk earlier, just buzzed and now I've got a mini-hangover. Like.. what's the point. I actually think I'm starting to hate alcohol. Which is awesome.
posts.Post Summary: The main self state in the post is adaptive and centers around the writer's desire to be well. It made him behave in a self-care way by not drinking during the weekend, resulting in him feeling proud of himself. his cognition of himself sounds positive as well, showing self compassion and recognition of improvement. the other self state in the post is maladaptive. it starts with the self-harm behavior shown where the writer buys and drinks alcohol. this behavior leads him to feel depressed, like garbage, and to criticize himself and his attraction to alcohol.

A.highlighted_evidence: I was feeling amazing this weekend after not drinking

B-S.highlighted_evidence: I was feeling amazing this weekend after not drinking.

C-S.highlighted_evidence: I think I'm starting to not enjoy alcohol.

D.highlighted_evidence: I actually think I'm starting to hate alcohol. Which is awesome.

posts.post:
My career/job is making me so fucking depressed
22 years old and I've finally landed a job with a livable wage and I absolutely hate it. My family expects me to stick with it. I don't even know what I'd do otherwise. I wish I could do something artsy or something semi-fun at least. There is nothing even semi-enjoyable about this job.   Thinking about my future I just see... nothing. I don't know what to do anymore. I can't keep going with my life if this is it for me. People are supposed to spend a good portion of their lives at work and I don't understand how they don't off themselves if this is what a "real job" is supposed to be.
posts.Post Summary: the main self state in the post is maladaptive and is focused on the writer keeping a job he hates, ignoring his needs and wants, fbecause he feels his family expects him to, hence forcing him. the situation makes him feel depressed,  expecting nothing to get better exhibiting hopelessness regarding the future. he criticizes himself when thinking about leaving, saying he won't know what to do.  the adaptive self state is composed of the writer's job to choose his own career path, wishing for these autonomy needs to be fulfilled, while keeping a job allowing him to take care of himself economically.

posts.post:
Is life SUPPOSED to be enjoyable?
Always hearing stories of older people talking about fun times when they were younger.   I'm 22 right now and it's always seemed so far-fetched. How do people even get in those fun situations? It seems like something you'd see in a movie.   I have almost no good memories in my life and now I'm at the point where I'm working full time at a job I hate so really considering killing myself but I'll likely try to become medicated enough to become docile and not care about how mundane my life is until I hopefully naturally die early (I drink a lot and don't take care of myself). I don't know how else I can handle it without killing myself.
posts.Post Summary: The main self state in the post is maladaptive. it centers the writer's depression, leading him to feel as if he has no good memories in life, criticizing himself, and to behave in harmful ways towards himself by drinking a lot. The writer idolizes others' viewing them as talking about how having fun is an experience not available for him as opposed to them. furthermore the writer expects things to not get better unless he kills himself. the adaptive self state is comprised of the decision to get medicated, showcasing self-care behavior.

B-S.highlighted_evidence: but I'll likely try to become medicated

A.highlighted_evidence: Is life SUPPOSED to be enjoyable?

B-S.highlighted_evidence: I drink a lot and don't take care of myself

D.Category: (6) Expectation that competence needs will not be met
D.highlighted_evidence: I don't know how else I can handle it without killing myself.

timeline_summary: The maladaptive self states in this post are characterized mostly by a depressive affect, an expectation that things will not get better, self critism and bad self-harm behavior (drinking) blocking any potential for improvement. the maladaptive self state is mostly dominant in the writer's experience. the adaptive self state is significantly less dominant, and is composed mainly of self-care behavior when the writer stops drinking, because of his desire to get better. The only time the adaptive voice is more dominant is when the writer goes to an AA meeting for the first time.
